revision.comment: removed [[Category:Polish nobility]] using [[WP:HC|HotCat]] Already in a noble family category
revision.text:
{{Infobox nobility| | name=Prince
Kazimierz Nestor Sapieha | image=[[File:Kazimier Niestar Sapieha. Казімер Нестар Сапега (J. Pitschmann, 1787).jpg|225px]]
Portrait by [[Józef Pitschmann]] (1787)
[[Image:Herb Sapiehów.PNG|120px]] | caption= | noble family=[[Sapieha]] | CoA=Lis | father=[[Jan Sapieha (died 1751)|Jan Sapieha]] | mother=[[Elżbieta Branicka (1734-1800)|Elżbieta Branicka]] | spouse-type=consort | spouse=[[Cetner family|Anna Cetner]] h. [[Przerowa Coat of Arms|Przerowa]] | children= | birth_date={{Birth date|1757|2|14|df=y}} | birth_place=[[Brześć Litewski]], [[Polish-Lithuanian Commonwealth]] | death_date={{dda|1798|5|25|1757|2|14|df=y}} | death_place= [[Vienna]], [[Austrian Empire]] }} Prince '''Kazimierz Nestor Sapieha''' (1757–1798) was a [[Poland|Polish]]-[[Lithuania]]n noble ([[szlachcic]]) and one the creators of the [[3 May Constitution]]. ==Biography== ===Early life and career=== Kazimierz Sapieha was educated at the [[Corps of Cadets (Warsaw)|Knight School]] in [[Warsaw]] from 1767 until 1771, and later studied in [[Italy]]. Upon his return he served as [[Artillery General of Lithuania]], from 1773 to 1793. As Deputy from [[Brzesc Litewski]], he participated in several [[Sejm]]s. Most notably, from 1790 he participated in the [[Sejm Wielki|Four-Year Sejm]] in Warsaw, and became [[Sejm Marshal]] from 6 October 1788 until 29 May 1792, and Marshal of the Lithuanian [[Confederation]]. ===Politics=== An early supporter of the [[magnate]] opposition to any liberalization (his uncle [[Hetman]] [[Franciszek Ksawery Branicki]] was its leader), Sapieha changed his position under the influence of [[Stanisław Małachowski]], and became a supporter of reforms, and the [[3 May Constitution]]. He strongly protested, when King [[Stanisław August Poniatowski]] joined the [[Targowica Confederation]], and this so angered Sapieha, that he decided to leave Poland. He briefly settled in [[Dresden]]. After the outbreak of the [[Kościuszko Uprising]], he returned to his homeland and participated in the uprising, holding the rank of an Artillery Captain. After the Uprising collapsed, he left Poland again, and spent the rest of his life in [[exile]] in [[Vienna]], where he died 1798. ==Awards== * Knight of the [[Order of the White Eagle (Poland)|Order of the White Eagle]], awarded on January 1, 1779. ==References== {{reflist|refs= {{cite book|author=Jacek Jędruch|authorlink=Jacek Jędruch|title=Constitutions, elections, and legislatures of Poland, 1493–1977: a guide to their history|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=Rmx8QgAACAAJ|accessdate=13 August 2011|year=1998|publisher=EJJ Books|isbn=978-0-7818-0637-4|pages=197–198}} }} {{Sejm Marshals of the Polish-Lithuanian Commonwealth}} {{Authority control}} {{DEFAULTSORT:Sapieha, Kazimierz Nestor}} [[Category:1757 births]] [[Category:1798 deaths]] [[Category:People from Brest, Belarus]] [[Category:Generals of the Polish–Lithuanian Commonwealth]] [[Category:Sapieha|Kazimierz Nestor]] [[Category:Polish generals]] [[Category:Lithuanian nobility]] [[Category:Members of the Great Sejm]] [[Category:Kościuszko insurgents]] [[Category:Recipients of the Order of Saint Stanislaus]] [[Category:Signers of the Polish Constitution of May 3, 1791]] [[Category:18th-century Polish politicians]] [[Category:18th-century Lithuanian people]] {{Poland-noble-stub}} {{Poland-mil-bio-stub}} {{Lithuania-noble-stub}}

==Military and political figures== [[File:Aleksander-d-store.jpg|thumb|[[Alexander the Great]], king of the city state of Macedon, tutored and personally mentored by [[Aristotle]], first united the Greek city states, then conquered the [[Persian Empire]] as well as Egypt; named and founded the city of [[Alexandria]].]]
===Ancient period=== * [[Agis III]] (r.338–?331 BCE), Spartan king who rebelled against Macedon in 331 BCE * [[Alcibiades]] (450–404 BCE), Athenian general and statesman * [[Alexander the Great]], (356–323 BCE) King of Macedon, and conqueror of the Persian Empire * [[Antiochus III the Great]], (c. 241–187 BCE) Seleucid Monarch * [[Antipater]], (c.390–319 BCE), Macedonian noble and Alexander the Great's regent in Macedon * [[Aristides]] (530–468 BCE), Athenian statesman * [[Cimon]] (510–450 BCE), Athenian leader and statesman * [[Cleopatra VII Thea Philopator]], (c.68–30 BCE) Queen of Egypt, from the Hellenistic Ptolemaic Dynasty [[File:Michelangelo, Cleopatra.jpg|thumb|Michelangelo's rendering of [[Cleopatra VII Thea Philopator]]]] * [[Demosthenes]] (384–322 BCE), politician and orator * [[Dionysius I of Syracuse|Dionysius I]] (c.432–367), ruler of the Syracusan empire * [[Epaminondas]] (c.420–362), Theban general and statesman * [[Eucratides]], ruler of the Bactrian Greeks * [[Leonidas I|Leonidas]] (d.480 BCE), Spartan king, killed defending Greece from the Persians [[File:Bust of Leonidas I.jpg|thumb|Bust of [[Leonidas I]], famed king of Sparta who led his troops at the [[Battle of Thermopylae]] against a Persian invasion of the Greek city states, perhaps most famous for having told the Persian King Xerxes his "[[Molon labe]]", or "Come and take them", when ordered to surrender and to give up his weapons once his unit's position had been betrayed and surrounded.]] * [[Lycurgus (Sparta)|Lycurgus]] (9th century BCE), semi-legendary Spartan lawgiver * [[Lysander]] (d395), Spartan general and hero during the [[Peloponnesian War]] * [[Memnon of Rhodes]], (d.333) Greek mercenary general in Persian army under Darius III * [[Miltiades the Younger|Miltiades]], Athenian statesman and general * [[Nearchus]], Alexander's naval commander * [[Peisistratos (Athens)|Peisistratus]], Athenian tyrant * [[Pericles]] (495–429 BCE), Athenian leader and statesman [[File:Marbles and bronzes; fifty plates from selected subjects in the Department of Greek and Roman Antiquities (1914) (14779575844).jpg|thumb|[[Pericles]], ''[[strategos]]'' of the city state of Athens during the [[Peloponnesian War]]]] * [[Philip II of Macedon]] (382–336 BCE), Macedonian king and father of Alexander the Great * [[Polycrates]], Samian ruler * [[Ptolemy I]] (c.356–285), Macedonian general under Alexander the Great, founded a dynasty in Egypt * [[Pyrrhus of Epirus]] (c.318–272), invaded Italy, became known for victories of dubious value (Pyrrhic) * [[Seleucus I]], Macedonian general under Alexander the Great, founded dynasty in Persia * [[Solon]] (638–558 BCE), Athenian lawmaker and [[archon]] * [[Themistocles]] (c.514–449 BCE), Athenian statesman and admiral * [[Xenophon]] (430–c.354 BCE), mercenary general, led and recounted march from Persia * [[Saint George]] (AD c.275–303), soldier in the Roman army, venerated as a Christian martyr
===Medieval period=== * [[Alexius I Comnenus]] (1048–1118), Byzantine Emperor * [[Basil II]] (963–1025), Emperor, known as the 'Bulgar-slayer' * [[Constantine Lascaris]], promoters of the revival of Greek learning in the [[Italian peninsula]] * [[Constantine VII]], Byzantine Emperor and scholar, 'born in the (Imperial) purple' (Porphyrogenitus) * [[Constantine XI]] (1405–1453), last Byzantine Emperor * [[Gemistus Pletho]], one of the chief pioneers of the revival of learning in [[Western Europe]]. * [[Helena of Constantinople|Helena]], Christian mother of Constantine I * [[Irene of Athens|Irene]], Byzantine Empress, instrumental in the restoration of icons, later sanctified * [[Johannes Bessarion]], Bishop and [[Cardinal (Catholicism)|Cardinal]] * [[Manuel Chrysoloras]], one of the pioneers in introducing Greek literature to western Europe. * [[Manuel I Comnenus]] (1143–1180), Byzantine Emperor, was responsible for a distinct revival of Byzantine fortunes until his defeat at Myriokephalon * [[Michael VIII Palaeologus]] (1159–1182), Byzantine (before 1261 Nicene) Emperor, recaptured Constantinople from the Franks. * [[Marcus Musurus]], professor of [[Greek language]] at the [[University of Padua]]. * [[Nicephorus II Phocas]] (963–969), Byzantine Emperor and general * [[Romanus IV]] (1068–1071), lost the fateful battle of [[Manzikert]] * [[Saints Cyril and Methodius|Saint Cyril]] (827–869), Byzantine monk, developed the [[Glagolitic alphabet]] * [[Theodora (wife of Justinian I)|Theodora]], wife of Justinian I, actress, courtesan, Empress.
===Ottoman Empire period=== * [[Atik Sinan]], architect for [[Mehmed II]] and [[Mustafa III]] * [[Aruj|Barbarossa]] (1473–1518), famous [[privateer]], older brother of [[Hayreddin Barbarossa|Khair ad Din]]; (Greek mother) * [[İbrahim Ethem Pasha]], Greek-born [[Grand Vizier]] * [[Hayreddin Barbarossa|Khair ad Din]] (1475–1546), Greek-born Ottoman Turkish Admiral, also known as Barbarossa; (Greek mother) * [[Pargalı İbrahim Pasha]], [[Suleyman the Magnificent]]'s first appointed Grand Vizier, who left an important landmark on his reign. * [[Alexandra Mavrokordatou]] (1605–1683), salonist and intellectual. * [[Mimar Sinan]], architect for [[Suleiman the Magnificent]] * [[Kosem Sultan]] * [[İshak Pasha]] Grand Vizier * [[Turgut Reis]] Ottoman Admiral * [[Al-Husayn I ibn Ali]] founder of the [[Husainid Dynasty]] of Tunisia

==List of Greeks who were born outside modern Greece== This is a list of [[ethnic Greeks]] who were born after the Declaration of the [[Greek War of Independence]] (1821), outside the borders of the [[Greece|Greek state]]. The list does not include Greeks born in the [[Greek diaspora|diasporan communities]] or [[Greek Cypriots|Greeks of Cyprus]] (after its independence in 1960), but only Greeks born in the traditional Greek homelands (the [[Balkans]], [[Anatolia]] and the [[East Mediterranean|Eastern Mediterranean]] shores).
===Actors/actresses===
* [[Cybele (actress)|Cybele]] (1887–1978): [[Smyrna]], {{flagicon|Ottoman Empire}} [[Ottoman Empire]] * [[Manos Katrakis]] (1908–1984): [[Crete]], [[File:Flag of Cretan State.svg|22px|border]] then an [[Cretan State|autonomous province]] of the [[Ottoman Empire]] * [[Alexis Minotis]] (1898–1990): [[Chania]], [[Crete]], {{flagicon|Ottoman Empire}} then part of the [[Ottoman Empire]] * [[Sotiris Moustakas]] (1940–2007): [[Limassol]], [[Cyprus]], {{flagicon image|Flag of Cyprus (1922–1960).svg}} then part of the [[British Empire]] * [[Sapfo Notara]] (1907–1985): [[Cretan State|Crete]], [[File:Flag of Cretan State.svg|22px|border]] then an [[Cretan State|autonomous province]] of the [[Ottoman Empire]] * [[Nikos Stavridis]] (1910–1987): [[Samos]], [[Principality of Samos]], then an autonomous principality under Ottoman suzerainty * [[Angelique Rockas]]
===Athletes===
* [[Pyrros Dimas]] (1971–): [[Himara]], {{flagicon|Albania}} [[Albania]] * [[Leonidas Sampanis]] (1971–): [[Korytsa]], {{flagicon|Albania}} [[Albania]] * [[Apostolos Nikolaidis (athlete)|Apostolos Nikolaidis]] (1896–1980): [[Plovdiv]], {{flagicon|Bulgaria}} [[Bulgaria]]
===Clerics===
* [[Archbishop Chrysanthus of Athens]] (1881–1949): [[Gratini]], [[Thrace]], {{flagicon|Ottoman Empire}} then part of the [[Ottoman Empire]] * [[Archbishop Spyridon of Athens]] (1873–1956): Chili, {{flagicon|Ottoman Empire}} [[Ottoman Empire]] * [[Ecumenical Patriarch Joachim III of Constantinople]] (1834–1912): [[Constantinople]], {{flagicon|Ottoman Empire}} [[Ottoman Empire]] * [[Ecumenical Patriarch Maximus V of Constantinople]] (1897–1972): [[Sinop, Turkey|Sinope]], {{flagicon|Ottoman Empire}} [[Ottoman Empire]] * [[Ecumenical Patriarch Athenagoras I of Constantinople]] (1886–1972): Vasilikón, [[Ioannina]], [[Epirus (region)|Epirus]], {{flagicon|Ottoman Empire}} then part of the [[Ottoman Empire]] * [[Archbishop Iakovos of America]] (1911–2005): [[Imbros]], {{flagicon|Ottoman Empire}} [[Ottoman Empire]] * [[Makarios III]] (1913–1977): [[Panagia, Paphos]], [[Cyprus]], {{flagicon image|Flag of Cyprus (1922–1960).svg}} then part of the [[British Empire]] * [[Ecumenical Patriarch Demetrius I of Constantinople]] (1914–1991): [[Constantinople]], {{flagicon|Ottoman Empire}} [[Ottoman Empire]] * [[Ecumenical Patriarch Bartholomew I of Constantinople]] (1940–): [[Imbros]], {{flagicon|Turkey}} [[Turkey]]
===Entrepreneurs===
* [[John D. Chandris]] (1890–1942): [[Chios]], {{flagicon|Ottoman Empire}} then part of the [[Ottoman Empire]] * [[Aristotle Onassis]] (1906–1975): [[Smyrna]], {{flagicon|Ottoman Empire}} [[Ottoman Empire]] * [[Basil Zaharoff]] (1849–1936): [[Muğla]], {{flagicon|Ottoman Empire}} [[Ottoman Empire]]
===Fashion designers===
* [[Bulgari|Sotirios Boulgaris]] (1857–1932): [[Paramythia]], [[Epirus (region)|Epirus]], {{flagicon|Ottoman Empire}} then part of the [[Ottoman Empire]]
===Filmmakers===
* [[Elia Kazan]] (1909–2003): [[Constantinople]], {{flagicon|Ottoman Empire}} [[Ottoman Empire]] * [[Michael Cacoyannis]] (1922–2011): [[Limassol]], [[Cyprus]], {{flagicon image|Flag of Cyprus (1922–1960).svg}} then part of the [[British Empire]]
===Military and political leaders===
* [[Stephanos Skouloudis]] (1838–1928): [[Constantinople]], {{flagicon|Ottoman Empire}} [[Ottoman Empire]]; [[Prime Minister of Greece]] * [[Georgios Theotokis]] (1844–1916): [[Corfu]], {{flagicon image|Flag of the United States of the Ionian Islands.svg}} [[United States of the Ionian Islands]] then part of the [[British Empire]]; Prime Minister of Greece * [[Spyridon Lambros]] (1851–1919): [[Corfu]], {{flagicon image|Flag of the United States of the Ionian Islands.svg}} United States of the Ionian Islands then part of the [[British Empire]]; Prime Minister of Greece * [[Themistoklis Sophoulis]] (1860–1949): [[Vathy, Samos]], [[File:Bandera de Samos.svg|22px]] then an autonomous principality under [[Ottoman Empire|Ottoman]] suzerainty; Prime Minister of Greece * [[Eleftherios Venizelos]] (1864–1936): [[Mournies]], [[Chania]], Crete, {{flagicon|Ottoman Empire}} then part of the [[Ottoman Empire]]; Prime Minister of Greece * [[Emmanouil Tsouderos]] (1882–1956): [[Rethymno]], [[Crete]], {{flagicon|Ottoman Empire}} then part of the [[Ottoman Empire]]; Prime Minister of Greece * [[Konstantinos Tsaldaris]] (1884–1970): [[Alexandria]], [[File:Flag of Egypt (1844-1867).svg|22px]] [[Khedivate of Egypt]], Prime Minister of Greece * [[Alexandros Svolos]] (1892–1956): [[Krusevo]], {{flagicon|Ottoman Empire}} [[Ottoman Empire]], Prime Minister of Greece * [[Sophoklis Venizelos]] (1894–1964): [[Chania]], Crete, {{flagicon|Ottoman Empire}} then part of the [[Ottoman Empire]]; Prime Minister of Greece * [[Evripidis Bakirtzis]] (1895–1947): [[Kozani]], [[Macedonia (Greece)|Macedonia]]; {{flagicon|Ottoman Empire}} then part of the [[Ottoman Empire]]; leader of the [[Political Committee of National Liberation]] during [[World War II]] * [[Konstantinos Karamanlis]] (1907–1998): [[Proti, Serres]], {{flagicon|Ottoman Empire}} then part of the [[Ottoman Empire]]; Prime Minister and then [[President of Greece]]
===Musicians===
* [[Manolis Kalomiris]] (1883–1962): [[Smyrna]], {{flagicon|Ottoman Empire}} [[Ottoman Empire]] * [[Rita Abatzi]] (1914–1969): [[Smyrna]], {{flagicon|Ottoman Empire}} [[Ottoman Empire]] * [[Marios Tokas]] (1954–2008): [[Limassol]], [[Cyprus]], {{flagicon image|Flag of Cyprus (1922–1960).svg}} then part of the [[British Empire]] * [[Iannis Xenakis]] (1922–2001): [[Brăila]], {{flagicon|Romania}} [[Romania]]

===Sculptors===
* [[Pavlos Prosalentis]] (1784–1837): [[Corfu]], {{flagicon|Republic of Venice}} [[Republic of Venice]] * [[Konstantinos Dimitriadis]] (1879 or 1881–1943): [[Asenovgrad|Stenimachos]], [[Eastern Rumelia]] * [[Costas Valsamis]] (1908–2003): [[Symi]], {{flagicon|Ottoman Empire}} [[Ottoman Empire]] * [[Dimitra Tserkezou]] (1920–2007): [[Constantinople]], {{flagicon|Ottoman Empire}} [[Ottoman Empire]]
===Singers===
* [[Alkistis Protopsalti]] (1954–): [[Alexandria]], {{flagicon|Egypt|1922}} [[Egypt]] * [[Anna Vissi]] (1957–): [[Larnaca]], {{flagicon image|Flag of Cyprus (1922–1960).svg}} [[Cyprus]] then part of the [[British Empire]] * [[Mario Frangoulis]] (1966–): [[Rhodesia]] (now [[Zimbabwe]]), Africa

Cavafy]] (1863–1933): [[Alexandria]], [[File:Flag of Egypt (1844-1867).svg|22px]] [[Egypt Province, Ottoman Empire|Ottoman Egypt]] * [[Nikos Kazantzakis]] (1883–1957): [[Heraklion]], [[Crete]], {{flagicon|Ottoman Empire}} then part of the [[Ottoman Empire]] * [[Kostas Varnalis]] (1884–1974): [[Burgas]], {{flagicon|Bulgaria}} [[Bulgaria]] * [[Giorgos Seferis]] (1900–1971): [[Urla, İzmir|Urla]], [[Smyrna]], {{flagicon|Ottoman Empire}} [[Ottoman Empire]] * [[Odysseas Elytis]] (1911–1996): [[Crete]], [[File:Flag of Cretan State.svg|22px|border]] then an [[Cretan State|autonomous province]] of the [[Ottoman Empire]] * [[Andreas Embirikos]] (1901–1975): [[Brăila]], {{flagicon|Romania}} [[Romania]] * [[Antigone Kefala]] (1935–): [[Brăila]], {{flagicon|Romania}} [[Romania]]

revision.comment: Robot - Moving category Arab people to [[:Category:Arabs]] per [[WP:CFD|CFD]] at [[Wikipedia:Categories for discussion/Log/2018 July 19]].
revision.text:
In Islamic tradition '''Lu'ayy ibn Ghalib''' ({{Lang-ar|لؤي بن غالب}}) was an ancestor of [[Muhammad]].
The tradition states that Muhammad was the son of 'Abdullah, b. 'Abdu'I-Muttalib (whose name was Shayba), b. [[Hashim]] (whose name was 'Amr), b. [[Abd Manaf]] (whose name was al-Mughira), b. Qusay (whose name was Zayd), b. [[Kilab]], b. [[Murrah ibn Ka'b|Murrah]], b. Ka'b, b. '''Lu'ayy''', b. Ghalib, b. [[Fihr]], b. [[Malik]], b. [[al-Nadr]], b. [[Kinana]], b. [[Khuzayma]], b. [[Mudrika]] (whose name was 'Amir), b. [[Ilyas]], b. [[Mudar]], b. [[Nizar (Ishmaelites)|Nizar]], b. [[Ma'add]], b. [[Adnan]], b. Udd (or Udad),....b. Ya'rub, b. Yashjub, b. [[Qedar]], b. [[Isma'il]], b. [[Ibrahim]], the friend of the Compassionate.<ref>{{ cite book |last1=Ibn Ishaq |last2= Guillaume |title=The Life of Muhammad: A Translation of Ibn Isḥāq’s sīrat|url= https://archive.org/stream/TheLifeOfMohammedGuillaume/The_Life_Of_Mohammed_Guillaume#page/n23/mode/2up |location=London |isbn=0195778286 |year=1955|page=3}}</ref> In [[Ibn Ishaq]]'s ''Biography of the Prophet Muhammad'' (as translated by [[Alfred Guillaume]]) he reports these stories:
"A soothsayer Shafi' b. Kulayb al-Sadafi had come to Yemen King [[Tubba (title)|Tubba']] and lived with him, and when he wished to bid him farewell Tubba' asked him whether he had anything of importance to communicate, and in the customary rhymes of saj' (light poems) he told him in reply to the question whether any king would fight with Tubba', "No, but the king of Ghassan had a son whose kingdom would be surpassed by a man of great piety, helped by the Almighty, described in the Psalms (of the Israelites); his people would be favoured by revelation, he would dispel darkness by light, Ahmad the prophet. How blessed his people when he comes, one of the descendants of '''Lu'ayy''' from Banu Qusayy. Tubba' sent for a copy of the psalms, examined them, and found the description of the prophet."
Lu'ay's grandson [[Qusay]] who conquered Mecca for Quraish said a poem taking pride in his grandfather '''Lu'ay''':
:I am the son of the protectors from Lu'ayy
:in Mecca is my house where I grew.
:mine is the valley as Ma'add knows,
:It is Marwa I delight in,
:I did not have to battle, had not,
:the sons of [[Qedar]] and [[Nabit]] settled here,
:Rizh is my helper I fear no injustice as long as I live".<ref>{{ cite book |author=Ibn Ishaq |author-link=Ibn Ishaq |translator= Alfred Guillaume |translator-link= Alfred Guillaume |title=The Life of Muhammad: A Translation of Ibn Isḥāq’s sīrat|url= https://archive.org/stream/TheLifeOfMohammedGuillaume/The_Life_Of_Mohammed_Guillaume#page/n73/mode/2up |location=London |isbn=0195778286 |year=1955|page=696,54}}</ref>

{{for|the British actor|Martin Savage (actor)}} {{Use dmy dates|date=October 2013}} {{Use Irish English|date=October 2013}} {{Infobox military person |name= '''Martin Savage'''
'''{{lang-ga|Máirtín Sabhaois}}''' |birth_date = 12th October 1897 |death_date = 19 December 1919 |birth_place= [[Ballisodare]], [[County Sligo]], [[Ireland]] |death_place= [[Ashtown (Dublin)|Ashtown]], [[County Dublin]], [[Ireland]] |image=Martin savage.jpg |caption= |nickname= |allegiance= [[Irish Republican Army]], [[Irish Volunteers]] |serviceyears= 1916 – 1919 |rank= [[Officer (armed forces)|Officer]] |commands= |unit=Dublin Brigade |battles= [[Easter Rising]], [[Irish War of Independence]] |awards= |laterwork= }} '''Martin Savage''' ({{lang-ga|Máirtín Sabhaois}}; 12 October 1897 – 19 December 1919) was an [[Officer (armed forces)|Officer]] in the Dublin Brigade of the [[Irish Republican Army]], from [[Ballisodare]], [[County Sligo]].Roger McDonnell On 19 December 1919 he was killed in a gun battle during an [[ambush]] at [[Ashtown (Dublin)|Ashtown]], near the border of [[County Meath]] and [[County Dublin]], during the early stages of the [[Irish War of Independence]]. ==Early life== Savage was born in Streamstown, [[Ballisodare]], [[County Sligo]] on 12 October 1897. He was the youngest son of Michael Savage who was known locally as a [[Fenian]] activist{{cite book |last=McTernan |first=John C. |title=Worthies Of Sligo, Profiles of Eminent Sligonians of Other Days |year=1994 |publisher=Avena Publications |location=Sligo|isbn=0-9520594-3-6|chapter=Patriot sons and daughters|page=210}} and Bridget Savage; formerly Gildea. After leaving school he worked as an apprentice grocer in [[Sligo Town]] before committing himself to the fight for Irish Independence.{{cite web | author=Unknown| title=Sinn Féin Easter commemorations | work=Leitrim Observer | url=http://www.leitrimobserver.ie/ViewArticle2.aspx?SectionID=2571&ArticleID=1423890 | accessdate=6 April 2006 }}{{cite web | author=Wayne Sugg| title=Christmas week ambush | work=An Phoblacht| url=http://republican-news.org/archive/1999/December16/16hist.html | accessdate=30 September 2006}}{{cite web | author=Unknown| title=Vol Martin Savage | work=PearseCom| url=http://www.pearsecom.com/Ireland/rebelsongs/ashtownroad.htm | accessdate=30 September 2006 }}{{cite web | author=Roger McDonnell| title=1901 Census Search | work=Leitrim Roscommon| url=http://www.leitrim-roscommon.com/cgi-bin/newcen-srch | accessdate=30 September 2006 }}{{cite web | author=Anna Ryan| title=Old Ballisodare Cemetery, County Sligo | work=Cemetery Transcription Library| url=http://interment.net/data/ireland/sligo/ballisadare/ballisadare.htm | accessdate=26 July 2001 }}{{cite web | author=Des Keenan| title=Ireland 1850-1920 | work=Des Keenan| url=http://www.deskeenan.org.uk/5NiChapter11.htm | accessdate=30 September 2006}} == Military action == Savage moved to [[Dublin]] in 1915 and joined the [[Irish Volunteers]]. As a 17-year-old he took part in the 1916 [[Easter Rising]] in Dublin and fought at the Four Courts.{{cite web|title=Roll of Honour|url=http://the1916proclamation.ie/the-roll-honour/s/|website=1916 proclamation|ref=9}} He was captured by the [[British Army]] and imprisoned in [[Richmond Barracks]]. On 30 April 1916 he was deported to [[Knutsford]] Detention Barracks in [[Cheshire]], [[England]] along with 200 other captured prisoners. Upon his release Savage returned to Dublin and re-engaged in paramilitary activity and became a [[Lieutenant]] in the 2nd Battalion of the Dublin Brigade. Within republican circles he was known as a shy, slim built, handsome Sligonian who was a popular and trusted especially amongst the likes of [[Dan Breen]], [[Seán Treacy]] and [[Seán Hogan]]. ''My Fight For Irish Freedom'', Dan Breen, 1989. PB) {{ISBN|0-947962-33-6}} p.85, p.90 - p.95, p.168 == The Ashtown ambush == ===Planning by Breen=== On 19 December 1919, Savage and 10 fellow Fenian paramilitaries, including Mick McDonnell, Tom Kehoe, [[Seán Treacy]], [[Séamus Robinson (Irish republican)|Séamus Robinson]], [[Seán Hogan]], [[Paddy Daly]] (Leader), Vincent Byrne, Tom Kilcoyne, Joe Leonard and [[Dan Breen]], met after planning to assassinate the then British [[Viceroy]], [[Lord Lieutenant of Ireland]] and Supreme Commander of the British Army in Ireland, [[John French, 1st Earl of Ypres|Lord John French]], as he returned from a private party which he had hosted the previous evening at his country residence in [[Frenchpark]], [[County Roscommon]].''My Fight For Irish Freedom'', Dan Breen, 1989. PB) {{ISBN|0-947962-33-6}} It was not originally planned that Savage was to take an active part in the ambush, however, after a chance meeting with Breen and Hogan, Savage insisted that he join the ambushing force. Sean Hogan initially attempted to dissuade him, but relented and gave Savage an automatic pistol. The unit's intelligence operative had informed it that Lord French would be travelling in the second car of the armed convoy that comprised an outrider and three following cars, which would bring Lord French from Ashtown railway station to the Vice-Regal Lodge in [[Phoenix Park]], Dublin.{{cite web | author=| title=Remembering Martin Savage| work=[[An Phoblacht]]| url=http://www.anphoblacht.com/news/detail/7791| accessdate=17 June 2007}} ===Events of the day=== On the day of the ambush, Savage attended work as usual and slipped away early in the morning to meet with the other men who were to take part in the attack who were gathered at Fleming's Pub in [[Drumcondra, Dublin|Drumcondra]]. They departed Drumcondra in small groups to avoid raising suspicion as they cycled through [[Phibsboro]] and up the [[Cabra, Dublin|Cabra]] Road, and then regrouped at Kelly's Public House (now called the Halfway House) in Ashtown. At approximately 11:40 a.m., as the train carrying Lord French pulled into the station, they left the pub and took up positions along the crossroads at Ashtown. The plan was for Martin Savage, Tom Kehoe and Dan Breen to push a hay-cart halfway across the road and then, after the out-rider and the first car had passed, they would push it the rest of the way across the road, thereby completely blocking the path of the remaining vehicles. They had been informed that Lord French was to be in the second car and this car they intended to attack with [[Mills Bomb]]s and rifle fire. As they pushed the hay-cart across the road their plan was almost foiled as a member of the [[Royal Irish Constabulary]] (RIC) disturbed them, telling them to move on. One of them threw a grenade at him, although it didn't explode it struck the police officer on the head, knocking him unconscious. The police officer was then dragged from the road and the attack went ahead as planned.Wayne Sugg ===Lord French's car and the gun battle=== When the convoy appeared minutes later the attack commenced, forcing the target second car in the convoy to swerve off the road. However, unknown to the attackers Lord French was travelling in the first car, which managed to drive through the blockade. The occupants of the second car, part of Lord French's guard, returned fire. As the gun battle developed the third car of the convoy arrived on the other side of the cart, and its occupants began firing with rifles on the now exposed ambushing force. In the exchange of fire Breen was shot in the leg, and seconds later Savage fell mortally wounded after being hit by a bullet in the neck. He died in the arms of Breen and his last words to Breen were "I'm done, but carry on....". Tom Kehoe and the wounded Breen succeeded in carrying Savage's body from the road and back to Kelly’s Pub while the gun battle continued.{{cite news | author=| title=No Fear!| work=[[TIME Magazine]]| url=http://www.time.com/time/magazine/article/0,9171,743678,00.html| accessdate=17 June 2007 | date=9 May 1932}} Two Royal Irish Constabulary police officers and a driver were also wounded in the gun battle. At this point the British military, including some wounded, began to withdraw from the scene and continued on towards the Phoenix Park. Knowing British reinforcements would be on their way, the IRA unit itself dispersing to safe houses in the Dublin area. Breen was helped onto his bike by [[Paddy Daly]] who helped him to a safehouse in the Phibsboro' area, where he was medically treated to by the captain of the [[Dublin]] [[hurling]] team, Dr J.M. Ryan. The next morning, the ''Irish Independent'' published an article which described the attackers as "assassins" and included other such terms as "criminal folly", "outrage" and "murder." Taking these terms as an insult to their dead comrade, it was decided to attack the newspaper's offices. On Sunday, at 9pm, between twenty and thirty IRA men under the direction of [[Peadar Clancy]] entered the offices of the ''Independent'' where they proceeded to wreck its machinery of production. Despite this, with the assistance of the other Dublin newspapers, the ''Independent'' was able to appear the next day, and the owners were awarded £16,000 pounds in compensation. According to Breen in his memoir, neither the ''Independent'', nor any other Dublin newspaper, ever dared refer to the IRA as 'murderers or assassins' again.Dan Breen, ''My Fight for Irish Freedom'', [Talbot Press, 1924], 1989, {{ISBN|978-0-947962-33-3}}. == Funeral == Savage's body was taken by British military and an inquest was held into his death. The inquest was attended by his brother and his employer William Kirk, who described the dead soldier as "a steady, sober and industrious young man, gentlemanly in manner and extremely courteous."{{cite book |last=McTernan |first=John C. |title=Worthies Of Sligo, Profiles of Eminent Sligonians of Other Days |year=1994 |publisher=Avena Publications |location=Sligo|isbn=0-9520594-3-6|chapter=Patriot sons and daughters|page=211}} After the inquest, Savage's body was handed over to his relatives. His remains lay overnight at [[Broadstone (Dublin) railway station|Broadstone Station]] before departing for Sligo where it was met at [[Collooney railway station]] by a large crowd.''My Fight For Irish Freedom'', Dan Breen, 1989. PB) {{ISBN|0-947962-33-6}} p.94 His coffin, draped in an Irish [[Tricolour (flag)|Tricolour]], was carried over two miles at shoulder height to his family's burial ground. It was buried with military honours in his native Ballisodare, County Sligo.{{cite book |last=McTernan |first=John C. |title=Worthies Of Sligo, Profiles of Eminent Sligonians of Other Days |year=1994 |publisher=Avena Publications |location=Sligo|isbn=0-9520594-3-6|pages=209–215|chapter=Patriot sons and daughters}} [[File:Martin Savage Terrace.jpg|thumb|right|250px|Street plaque at Martin Savage Terrace, [[Sligo]].]] Breen noted that "the cortege was several miles long, the Parish Priest attended and recited the last prayer, while the Royal Irish Constabulary, armed with guns, surrounded the graveyard. "However, I suppose, this was the best tribute they could have paid to a gallant soldier, even though they did not mean it that way".''My Fight For Irish Freedom'', Dan Breen, 1989. PB) {{ISBN|0-947962-33-6}} p.95 == Legacy of Martin Savage == [[File:Martinsavage 2007.jpg|thumb|Poster for Volunteer Martin Savage Commemoration]] [[File:MARTIN SAVAGE RELATIVES.jpg|top|thumb|12 December 2009 - Relatives of IRA Volunteer Martin Savage pictured at a commemoration to mark the 90th anniversary of his death. Also pictured are Sinn Féin Vice President Mary Lou McDonald and Dublin West representative Paul Donnelly]] [[File:CARRICK-ON-SUIR RFB.jpg|left|thumb|The Carrick-on-Suir Republican Flute Band pictured at the Volunteer Martin Savage Commemoration, Saturday 12 December 2009]] [[File:Volunteer Joe McDonnell Sinn Féin Cumann Banner.jpg|top|thumb|[[Sinn Féin]] supporters carry this banner at their annual commemoration to highlight the similarities between the fight for Independence in the early twentieth century and the republican struggle through the decades right up until present day.]] In 1948, the [[National Graves Association]] erected a memorial to Savage close to the site of the ambush at Ashtown Cross. There is an annual commemoration of his death at the site of the ambush.JmcDMFB{{cite web | author=| title=3rd Annual Volunteer Martin Savage Commemoration| work=Dublin West Sinn Féin| url=http://www.dublinwestsinnfein.ie/news/656| accessdate=17 June 2007}}{{cite web | author=| title=Martin Savage Commemoration| work=Dublin West Sinn Féin| url=http://dublinsinnfein.com/news/2534| accessdate=17 June 2007}} There have also been a number of streets and public places named after him including Martin Savage Place in [[County Meath]], Martin Savage Road and the home of [[Kinvara|Kinvara Ards]], Martin Savage Park in [[County Dublin]] and Martin Savage Terrace near the centre of [[Sligo]] Town.{{cite web | author=| title=Eastáit tionsclaíocha | work=Ainmneacha sráide Bhaile Átha Cliat | url=http://www.iol.ie/~sob/sraid/tablaJN.html| accessdate=17 June 2006}}[http://www.phoenixfc.ie/history.html Homepage of Kilnavara Ards] {{webarchive|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20070928193125/http://www.phoenixfc.ie/history.html |date=28 September 2007 }} The Ashtown Fianna Fáil Cumann, named after Savage, hold an annual commemoration on the Sunday after the anniversary of his death at the Ashtown memorial site. Since 2002, the [[Sinn Féin]] [[Joe McDonnell (hunger striker)|Joe McDonnell]] [[Cumann]] hold an annual rally on the anniversary of his death also. The Coen/Savage (East Sligo) [[Sinn Féin]] [[Cumann]] also hold a wreath laying ceremony every Easter Sunday morning at Martin Savage's graveside in Ballisodare, Co. Sligo. ==References== {{Reflist}} ==External links== *http://www.irish-folk-songs.com/ashtown-road-irish-rebel-song-lyrics-and-chords.html - The lyrics to a song written in memory of Martin Savage titled Ashtown Road. {{Easter Rising}} {{DEFAULTSORT:Savage, Martin}} [[Category:1897 births]] [[Category:1919 deaths]] [[Category:People from County Sligo]] [[Category:Irish Republican Army (1919–22) members]] [[Category:People killed in the Irish War of Independence]] [[Category:People of the Easter Rising]] [[Category:Irish Republicans killed during the Irish War of Independence]]

{{EngvarB|date=May 2018}} {{Use dmy dates|date=May 2018}} {{Infobox football biography | name = Matlan Marjan | image = | fullname = Matlan bin Marjan | birth_date = {{birth date and age|df=yes|1968|10|18}} | birth_place = [[Kota Belud]], [[Sabah]], [[Malaysia]] | height = | currentclub = | clubnumber = | position = [[Striker (football)|Forward]] | youthyears1 = 1987–1988 | youthclubs1 = [[Sabah FA|Sabah Presidents Cup Team's]] | nationalyears1 = 1991–1995 | years1 = 1989–1995 | clubs1 = [[Sabah FA]] | caps1 = <!--567--> | goals1 = <!--750--> | nationalteam1 = [[Malaysia national football team|Malaysia]] | nationalcaps1 = 18 | nationalgoals1 = 11 | pcupdate = | ntupdate = }}
'''Matlan Marjan''' is a former professional football player from the state of [[Sabah]], [[Malaysia]]. He is celebrated as the person who scored 2 goals against [[England national football team|England]] A team for [[Malaysia national football team|Malaysia]] on 12 June 1991, the only Malaysian to have done that.<ref>[http://www.englandfc.com/MatchData/yearbyyear.php?start=1990&end=1995&gender=M&level=FULL Results: 1990–1995] {{webarchive|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20131029195939/http://www.englandfc.com/MatchData/yearbyyear.php?start=1990&end=1995&gender=M&level=FULL |date=29 October 2013 }}, ''England F. C.''. Accessed 21 September 2007.</ref> He has a younger brother, [[Zainizam Marjan]] who also played for [[Sabah FA]] and [[Malaysia national football team|Malaysia]].
Matlan is a [[Bajau|Sabahan Bajau]] from [[Kota Belud]], [[Sabah]]. He started his professional career by playing in the Presidents Cup. He made his M-League debut in 1989 season by scoring 5 league goals. In 1990, he scored 8 of [[Sabah FA]] 16 goals.
In 1991, Matlan earned his first call-up for the national team for a friendly match with [[Aston Villa F.C.|Aston Villa]]. On 12 June 1991, he made his full international debut against [[England national football team|England]] as he equalled the 35-year record of [[Toni Fritsch]] as the latest new cap to score twice against England.<ref>[http://www.thefa.com/England/SeniorTeam/Archive/matchstats.html?m=393 The FA Match Statistics]</ref>
In 1995, he made history by becoming the first player from Sabah to captain the national team in the match against [[Clube de Regatas do Flamengo|Flamengo XI]].
In the same year, Matlan, along with five other Sabah FA players, was arrested on suspicion of match-fixing. Although the charges against the six were dropped<ref>[http://groups.google.com/group/bit.listserv.berita/browse_thread/thread/94908376a6cd6de8/f87e5c049e1838da?lnk=st&q=matlan+marjan&rnum=25&hl=en#f87e5c049e1838d "No charges against Sabah six"], ''Bernama''. Accessed 21 September 2007. </ref> he was severely punished, thus ending his football career. He was [[exile|banished]] to another [[Districts of Malaysia|district]].<ref>[http://groups.google.com/group/bit.listserv.berita/browse_thread/thread/da1e8985d90b96e8/bfe31352b1a30e94?lnk=st&q=matlan+marjan&rnum=22&hl=en#bfe31352b1a30e94 "Four Sabah soccer players banished to remote areas"], ''Bernama''. Accessed 21 September 2007.</ref>
== Honours == * [[Malaysia FA Cup]] 1995 Winners * [[Malaysia FA Cup]] 1994 Runners-up
== References == <references />
{{Malaysia-footy-bio-stub}}
{{DEFAULTSORT:Marjan, Matlan}} [[Category:1968 births]] [[Category:Living people]] [[Category:Bajau people]] [[Category:People from Sabah]] [[Category:Sabah FA players]] [[Category:Association football forwards]] [[Category:Malaysian footballers]] [[Category:Malaysia international footballers]]

revision.comment: Adding local [[Wikipedia:Short description|short description]]: "Type of spy" ([[User:Galobtter/Shortdesc helper|Shortdesc helper]])
revision.text:
{{short description|Type of spy}} In [[espionage]] jargon, a '''mole''' (also called a "penetration agent",<ref name="Smith" /> "deep cover agent", or "[[sleeper agent]]") is a long-term [[spy]] (espionage agent) who is recruited before having access to secret intelligence, subsequently managing to get into the target organization.<ref name="Green" /> However, it is popularly used to mean any long-term clandestine spy or [[informant]] within an organization, government or private.<ref name="Green" />
The term was introduced to the public by [[United Kingdom|British]] spy novelist [[John Le Carré]] in his 1974 novel ''[[Tinker, Tailor, Soldier, Spy]]''<ref name="Carlisle" /><ref name="Shapiro" /> and has since entered general usage, but its origin is unclear,<ref name="Smith" /> as well as to what extent it was used by [[Intelligence agency|intelligence services]] before it became popularized. Le Carré, a former British [[intelligence officer]], has said that the term mole was actually used by the [[USSR|Soviet]] intelligence agency, the [[KGB]],<ref name="Green" /> and that a corresponding term used by Western intelligence services was ''sleeper agent''.<ref name="Bruccoli2" /> While the term ''mole'' had been applied to spies in the book ''Historie of the Reign of King Henry VII'' written in 1626 by Sir [[Francis Bacon]],<ref name="Smith" /><ref name="Green" /> Le Carré has said he did not get the term from that source.
==Overview== A mole may be recruited early in life, and take decades to get a job in government service and reach a position of access to secret information before becoming active as a spy. Perhaps the most famous examples of moles were the [[Cambridge Five]], five upper-class British men recruited by the [[KGB]] as left-wing students at [[Cambridge University]] in the 1930s who later rose to high levels in various parts of the [[British government]].<ref name="Carlisle" /> By contrast, most espionage agents, such as CIA Director of Counterintelligence [[Aldrich Ames]] and FBI agent [[Robert Hanssen]], who spied on the US government for the KGB, were either recruited or offer their services as spies after they were in place as members of the target organization.
Because their recruitment occurred in the remote past, moles are difficult for a nation's security services to detect. The possibility that a top politician, corporate executive, government minister, or officer in an intelligence service could be a mole working for a foreign government is the worst nightmare of [[counterintelligence]] services. For example, [[James Angleton]], director of counterintelligence for the [[CIA]] between 1954 and 1975, was reportedly obsessed with suspicions that the top levels of Western governments were riddled with long-term communist agents<ref name="Smith"/> and accused numerous politicians such as former U.S. Secretary of State [[Henry Kissinger]], former Canadian Prime Ministers [[Lester Pearson]] and [[Pierre Trudeau]], former British Prime Minister [[Harold Wilson]] and many members of Congress before he was removed in 1975. Fears of such moles in prominent positions in American life led to overreactions such as [[McCarthyism]].
Moles have been featured in numerous espionage films, television shows, and novels.
==Reasons for use== The most common procedure used by [[intelligence services]] to recruit agents is to find the location within the foreign government or organization of the information they want (the ''target''), find out which people have access to it, and attempt to recruit one of them as a spy (''agent'') to obtain the information. However, the people with access to top secret government information, government employees with high [[security clearance]]s, are carefully monitored by the government's security apparatus for just this sort of espionage approach. Thus, it is difficult for a representative of the foreign intelligence service to meet with them clandestinely to recruit them. Private organizations such as large [[corporation]]s or [[terrorist group]]s have similar security monitors. In addition, the security clearance process weeds out employees who are openly disgruntled, ideologically disaffected, or otherwise have motives for betraying their country, so people in such positions are likely to reject recruitment as spies. Therefore, some intelligence services have tried to reverse the above process by first recruiting potential agents and then having them conceal their allegiance and pursue careers in the target government agency in the hope that they can reach positions of access to desired information.
Because the spy career of a mole is such a long-term one, sometimes occupying most of a lifetime, persons who become moles must be highly motivated. One common motivation is ideology (political convictions). During the [[Cold War]] a major source of moles in Western countries was so-called [[fellow traveller]]s, Westerners who, in their youth in the 1920s to 1940s, became disaffected with their own governments and sympathetic to world [[communism]] without actually joining the [[Communist Party]].
==See also== * [[Agent of influence]] * [[Double agent]] * [[Industrial espionage|Economic and industrial espionage]] * [[Insider threat]] * [[Traitor]] * ''[[The Mole (TV series)|The Mole]]'' (TV series)
== References == {{Reflist |refs= <ref name="Smith"> {{cite book | last = Smith | first = W. Thomas | title = [[Encyclopedia of the Central Intelligence Agency]] | publisher = [[Infobase Publishing]] | year = 2003 | location = Manhattan, New York City, USA | isbn = 9781438130187 | oclc = 586163250 | page = 171 }}
</ref><ref name="Green"> {{cite book | last = Green | first = Jonathon | title = Cassell's Dictionary of Slang: A Major New Edition of the Market-Leading Dictionary of Slang | publisher = [[Sterling Publishing]] | date = March 28, 2006 | location = New York City, New York, USA | url = https://books.google.com/books?id=5GpLcC4a5fAC&pg=PA953&dq=mole+%22john+le+carre%22+tinker&hl=en&sa=X&ei=Qv2KT4faB8rViAKx3q3fCw&ved=0CF0Q6AEwBQ#v=onepage&q=mole%20%22john%20le%20carre%22%20tinker&f=false | accessdate = August 26, 2012 | edition = 2nd, revised | isbn = 9780304366361 | oclc = 62890128 | page = 953 }} </ref>
<ref name="Carlisle"> {{cite book | last = Carlisle | first = Rodney P. | title = Complete Idiot's Guide to Spies and Espionage | publisher = [[Alpha Books]] | date = April 1, 2003 | location = Indianapolis, Indiana, USA | url = https://books.google.com/books?id=wZt283WNub4C&pg=PA142&dq=%22the+term+mole%22+%22john+le+carre%22&hl=en&sa=X&ei=6gOLT-rZCZDZiAKdqez_Cw&sqi=2&ved=0CF0Q6AEwBQ#v=onepage&q=%22the%20term%20mole%22%20%22john%20le%20carre%22&f=false | accessdate = August 26, 2012 | edition = illustrated | isbn = 9780028644189 | oclc = 52090218 | page = 142 }} </ref>
<ref name="Shapiro"> {{cite book | last = Shapiro | first = Fred R. | title = The Yale Book of Quotations | publisher = [[Yale University Press]] | date = Oct 30, 2006 | location = New Haven, Connecticut, USA | url = https://books.google.com/books?id=ck6bXqt5shkC&pg=PA448&dq=%22the+term+mole%22+%22john+le+carre%22&hl=en&sa=X&ei=6gOLT-rZCZDZiAKdqez_Cw&sqi=2&ved=0CGMQ6AEwBg#v=onepage&q=%22the%20term%20mole%22%20%22john%20le%20carre%22&f=false | accessdate = August 26, 2012 | edition = illustrated | isbn = 9780300107982 | oclc = 66527213 | page = 448 | quote = According to the ''Oxford English Dictionary'' "it is generally thought that the world of espionage adopted [the term mole] from Le Carré, rather than vice versa. }} </ref>
<ref name="Bruccoli2"> {{cite book | last1 = Le Carré | first1 = John | last2 = Bruccoli | first2 = Matthew J | last3 = Baughman | first3 = Judith | title = Conversations with John le Carré | publisher = [[University Press of Mississippi]] | year = 2004 | location = Jackson, Mississippi, USA | url = https://books.google.com/books?id=jxPWT_Lo5yQC&pg=PA33&lpg=PA33&dq=lamplighters+scalphunters&source=bl&ots=1bndhjJmBC&sig=Xg515esVIbk73L3Xx1ldZ971kDg&hl=en&sa=X&ei=6qPqToaFPOTE4gS4oPCCCQ&sqi=2&redir_esc=y#v=onepage&q=mole&f=false | accessdate = August 26, 2012 | edition = illustrated | isbn = 9781578066698 | oclc = 55019020 | pages = 33–34 | quote = interview with Le Carré in Melvyn Bragg ''The Listener'', January 22, 1976 BBC1, (reprint) }} </ref> }}
;Further reading * {{cite book | author = Staff | title = Why Do We Say It?: the stories behind the words, expressions and cliches we use | url = https://books.google.com/books?id=5qpIPQAACAAJ&dq=isbn:1555210104 | accessdate = August 26, 2012 | edition = reissue | date = November 29, 2009 | publisher = Castle Books | location = Secaucus, New Jersey, USA | isbn = 9781555210106 | oclc = 237155763 }}
{{DEFAULTSORT:Mole (Espionage)}} [[Category:Spies by role]] [[Category:Security breaches]]

{{Infobox person | name = H. Muammar Z.A | image = Muammar za.jpg | image_size = 222 | caption = | birth_name = Muammar Zainal Asykin | birth_date = 14 June 1954 aged 63<ref>{{citation | title= H. Muammar ZA; Qari dan Penghapal al-Quran | work= Muslihin | date= 25 June 2013 | url= http://www.mushlihin.com/2013/06/profile/h-muammar-za-qari-dan-penghapal-al-quran.php | accessdate= 23 January 2017}}</ref> | birth_place = [[Pemalang Regency|Pemalang]], [[Central Java]], [[Indonesia]] | death_date = | death_place = | nationality = [[Indonesia]]n | residence = | other_names = | known_for = Legendary reciter of the [[Quran]] in Indonesia | education = | employer = | occupation = [[Qari]] | Fields = | title = [[Kyai]] [[Hajji|Haji]], [[Ustad]], [[Hafiz (Quran)|Hafiz]] | salary = | networth = | height = | weight = | term = | predecessor = | successor = | party = | boards = | spouse = Syarifah Nadiya | partner = | children = Lia Farah Diza, Ahmad Syauqi Al Banna, Husnul Adib Al Fasyi, Rayhan Al Bazzy, and Ammar Luaiyan Ad Daany. | parents = H. Zainal Asyikin and Hj. Mu’minatul Afifah | relatives = Imron Rosyadi Z.A. | signature = | website = | footnotes = }}
'''[[Qari]] Muammar Zainal Asykin''' ([[Arabic]]: '''معمر زين العاشقين''', ''Mu'ammar Zayn-al Ashqeen''; born 14 June 1954) sometimes shortened '''Muammar ZA''' or '''Muammar Za''' is a popular senior [[Qari]] or [[Quran]] [[Qur'an reading|reciter]] and [[Hafiz (Quran)|Hafiz]] from [[Indonesia]] well known nationally and internationally. He won Qur'an Recitation Contests known as ''"[[Musabaqah Tilawatil Quran]]"'' ("MTQ") during the 1980s in Indonesia and abroad. His talent was recognised during childhood in his hometown [[Pemalang Regency|Pemalang]] where he participated and won a local children's Quran Competition in 1962 when he was just 7 years of age<ref name="Muammar">{{citation | title= Biografi H. Muammar ZA. | work= AR | publisher= Pecinta Qiro'ah Indonesia | date= 25 March 2013 | url= https://pecintaqiroah.wordpress.com/2013/03/25/biografi-h-muammar-za/ | accessdate= 23 January 2017}}</ref> H. Muammar, a national reciter, was renowned internationally for his breath capacity (the longest in the world, it was said).<ref name=anna>Anna M. Gade, [https://books.google.co.id/books?id=obCJrflCCHIC&pg=PA184&dq=muammar+za&hl=en&sa=X&ved=0ahUKEwj9iPzH_djRAhUgTY8KHW2UCwYQ6AEIHjAA#v=onepage&q=muammar%20za&f=false Perfection Makes Practice: Learning, Emotion, and the Recited Qurʼān in Indonesia], pg. 184. [[Honolulu]]: [[University of Hawaii Press]], 2004. {{ISBN|9780824825997}}</ref>
He is known to have a myriad of achievements related to [[Qur'an reading]] competitions. In 1967 he achieved the first place in the [[Quran]] Reciting Competition ("MTQ") of [[Jogjakarta]] Province, and after that winning in 1972 and 1973 representing [[Jogjakarta]] province in the national level of Quran Reciting Competition in [[Indonesia]]. In 1979 and 1986 he won the International level Quran Reciting Competition, and because of his achievements, he was invited to recite in [[Istana Nurul Iman]] of [[Brunei]], National Palace of [[Malaysia]], and until the [[Middle East]].<ref>{{citation | title= [Video] Qori’ Internasional KH Muammar ZA: Baca Al-Qur’an Langgam Jawa Dilarang Nabi | work= Cholis Akbar | publisher= Panji Islam | date= 22 May 2015 | url= http://www.hidayatullah.com/berita/nasional/read/2015/05/22/70192/video-qori-internasional-kh-muammar-za-baca-al-quran-langgam-jawa-dilarang-nabi.html | accessdate= 23 January 2017}}</ref>
He was invited by [[Jamia Binoria]] to recite the Quran in [[Pakistan]] in 2009.<ref>[https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=fPqmnMjz8Qw Qari Muammar reciting in Pakistan]</ref><ref>[https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=ocHlEkmd6EM Qari Muammar reciting in Pakistan]</ref><ref>[https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=cVUcQtU4hlc Qari Muammar reciting in Pakistan]</ref> He was also invited to recite in [[Turkey]] (''IGMG Aileler Günü'') in 2004.<ref>[https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=gpEHJa6tvhA Qari Muammar reciting in Turkey]</ref>
==Background== Qari Muammar is the seventh child of ten, of which only nine lived up-to adulthood, of H. Zainal Asykin and Hj. Mu’minatul Afifah who were religious figures of their home village. Qari Muammar was born in Moga district which is approximately 40 km south from the capital city of [[Pemalang Regency]] in [[Central Java]]. He has a younger brother named Imron Rosyadi Z.A who has followed in his brother's footsteps to become a [[Qari]]. Muammar married a woman from [[Aceh]] named Syarifah Nadiya in 1984 and has a daughter and four sons.<ref name="Muammar" />
In 2002, Muammar established an Islamic Boarding School known as "[[Pesantren]]" called "Pesantren Ummul Qura" ([[Arabic]]: '''أم القرى''') located in [[Cipondoh]], [[Tangerang]] to build future professional [[Qari]]s from a young age.<ref>{{citation | title= Pondok Pesantren Qori’ dan Qori’ah di Indonesia | publisher= rejekinomplok.net | url= http://rejekinomplok.net/pondok-pesantren-qori-dan-qoriah-di-indonesia/#3_Ponpes_Ummul_Qura | accessdate= 23 January 2017}}</ref>
==See also== *[[Maria Ulfah]] *[[Mu'min Ainul Mubarak]]
== References == {{Reflist|2}} {{Recitors of the Quran}} {{Islam in Indonesia}} [[Category:1954 births]] [[Category:Indonesian Muslims]] [[Category:Indonesian Quran reciters]] [[Category:Javanese people]] [[Category:Quran reciters]] [[Category:Living people]]

{{third-party|date=October 2017}} {{Orphan|date=October 2017}} [[File:Rakesh Shukla Founder and CEO TWB and VOSD.jpg|thumb|Rakesh Shukla, Founder and CEO, TWB and VOSD]] '''Rakesh Shukla''' is a [[Bangalore]]-based [[entrepreneur]], [[motivational speaker]], and [[animal welfare]] activist who runs a home for over 700 rescued dogs.<ref>{{cite news|title=TWB gives chance to rewrite your success story|url=http://www.indiainfoline.com/article/news/twb-gives-chance-to-rewrite-your-success-story-5723109854_1.html|accessdate=26 May 2017}}</ref><ref>{{cite news|title=Meet Rakesh Shukla: From a techie to being Bengaluru's dog rescuer|url=http://economictimes.indiatimes.com/magazines/panache/meet-rakesh-shukla-from-a-techie-to-being-bengalurus-dog-rescuer/articleshow/47673009.cms|accessdate=26 May 2017|work=The Economic Times|date=15 June 2015}}</ref><ref>{{cite news|title=Dog Activists Afrakesre 'Bitch', Ergo...|url=http://bangaloremirror.indiatimes.com/bangalore/cover-story/vosd-founder-public-helpline-street-dogs-voice-of-stray-dogs-animal-rights-activists-facebook/articleshow/42290124.cms?|accessdate=26 May 2017|publisher=Bangalore Mirror|date=11 September 2014}}</ref><ref name="BBC1">{{cite news|title=The man who looks after 735 dogs|url=https://www.bbc.com/news/world-asia-india-38303320|accessdate=26 May 2017|publisher=BBC News|date=19 December 2016}}</ref> He received a Bachelors of Engineering degree Electronics and Communications, then a Masters n Business Administration degree, and then worked in various telecom companies{{Specify |reason=Company names need to be specified. |date=October 2017}} in India, the US, and Singapore before becoming an entrepreneur.<ref>{{Cite web|url=https://in.linkedin.com/in/rakeshshukla|title=Rakesh Shukla, Founder & CEO, TWB_|last=|first=|date=|website=LinkedIn|archive-url=|archive-date=|dead-url=|access-date=}}</ref>
==Entrepreneurship==
Shukla pioneered technology content creation<ref>{{Cite web|url=https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=VjoTHEWtXRs|title=Young Turks On The Road Bengaluru Episode 3 Part 1 - The Writers Block|website=YouTube|language=en|access-date=2017-09-30}}</ref> by creating The Writers Block (TWB) in 2006 and grew his bootstrapped personally funded company<ref>{{Cite web|url=https://www.franchiseindia.com/entrepreneur/article/managing-a-business/finance/The-story-of-self-funding-an-enterprise-250/|title=The story of self-funding an enterprise|last=|first=|date=26 May 2010|website=franchiseindia.com|archive-url=|archive-date=|dead-url=|access-date=}}</ref> into a worldwide leader. He went on to create the first content automation solution in India and led to TWB to become the largest India-based pure-play technical publications vendor.
==Philanthropy==
Through TWB, Shukla has focused on creating opportunities for women in the workforce<ref>{{Cite web|url=http://www.livemint.com/Politics/7qvsPxu47L34kwBGtRneyL/Employers-seek-out-stayathome-moms.html|title=Employers seek out stay-at-home moms - Livemint|website=www.livemint.com|access-date=2017-09-30}}</ref> by employing a large proportion and speaking for them. He later institutionalized health care and opportunities for rural women through his non-profit VOSD{{Definition needed|date=October 2017}} for People.<ref>{{Cite web|url=https://www.facebook.com/vosdforpeople/|title=VOSD for People|website=www.facebook.com|language=en|access-date=2017-09-30}}</ref>
==Animal welfare==
Labeled "The Dogfather of India"<ref>{{Cite news|url=https://www.thequint.com/life/2017/03/29/rakesh-shukla-is-called-the-dogfather-of-india-for-taking-care-of-old-retired-patriot-dogs-that-served-the-country|title=In Pics: One Man is Giving Retired, Old Dogs a New Lease of Life|work=The Quint|access-date=2017-09-30|language=en}}</ref> or “Dog Whisperer”,<ref name="BM1">{{Cite web|url=http://bangaloremirror.indiatimes.com/rakesh-shukla-the-voice-of-stray-dogs-bangalore-mirror-heroes/amp_articleshow/24444683.cms|title=The Dog Whisperer - Bangalore Mirror|website=bangaloremirror.indiatimes.com|language=en|access-date=2017-09-30}}</ref> he set about creating VOSD after the press reported the death of a two-year-old boy named Sandeep in July 2011, reportedly killed and eaten by stray dogs.<ref name=BM1 /> Alarmed by calls to cull what are lawfully protected animals since 2001,<ref>{{Cite web|url=https://awbi.org/awbi-pdf/notification.pdf|title=ABC Rules 2001|last=|first=|date=|website=awbi.org|archive-url=|archive-date=|dead-url=|access-date=}}</ref> Shukla carried out independent investigations including a second autopsy, and came away with evidence that shifted the blame away from the dogs.<ref name=BM1 /> These were first published on the VOSD website in July 2010,<ref>{{Cite news|url=http://www.thehindu.com/features/metroplus/when-man-becomes-a-dogs-best-friend/article7833153.ece|title=When man becomes a dog's best friend|last=Datta|first=Sravasti|date=2015-11-02|work=The Hindu|access-date=2017-09-30|language=en-IN|issn=0971-751X}}</ref> and since then VOSD has conducted hundreds of investigations<ref>{{Cite news|url=http://www.strays.in/index.php/2011/09/aws-bangalore-on-8-sept-2011-the-killing-continues/|title=AWS Bangalore on 8 Sept 2011: The killing continues!! - The Voice of Stray Dogs|date=2011-09-09|work=The Voice of Stray Dogs|access-date=2017-09-30|language=en-US}}</ref> leading to the closure of rogue NGOs. Shukla resigned from the board of the [[Animal Welfare Board of India]] in 2012, citing pressure from within the board to change many investigations carried out as a member.<ref>{{Cite web|url=https://www.facebook.com/notes/the-voice-of-stray-dogs/resignation-from-the-co-opted-member-status-of-awbi/377691905607881/|title=Resignation from the Co-opted member status of AWBI|website=www.facebook.com|language=en|access-date=2017-09-30}}</ref> With the eventual death of Cookie, a paralyzed [[St. Bernard (dog)|St. Bernard]] found in garbage in Bangalore in September 2012,<ref>{{Cite news|url=http://bangaloremirror.indiatimes.com/columns/sunday-read//articleshow/21299399.cms?|title=This Cookie refused to crumble - Bangalore Mirror -|work=Bangalore Mirror|access-date=2017-09-30}}</ref> he set about creating the largest rescue of its kind in any city of the world.<ref>{{Cite web|url=http://www.odditycentral.com/animals/the-dog-father-indian-man-takes-care-of-735-dogs-that-nobody-else-wants.html|title=The Dog Father - Indian Man Takes Care of 735 Dogs That Nobody Else Wants|website=www.odditycentral.com|language=en-US|access-date=2017-09-30}}</ref> To ensure that no pressure is brought by government agencies to kill or remove dogs, VOSD is not funded by any government agency directly or indirectly.<ref name=BBC1 />
==Recognition==
Rakesh Shukla was named one of Bangalore's Heroes in 2013.<ref name="BM1"/> He speaks on behalf of dogs on television, radio, Internet radio, and newspaper interviews, including the [[BBC]],<ref name="BBC1"/> [[Al Jazeera]],<ref>{{Cite web|url=https://www.facebook.com/ajplusenglish/videos/vb.407570359384477/912550668886441/?type=2&theater|title=AJ+|website=www.facebook.com|language=en|access-date=2017-09-30}}</ref> [[CNN IBN]],<ref>{{Citation|last=Rakesh Shukla|title=CNN IBN 'India Positive' features 'The Voice of Stray Dogs'|date=2013-12-17|url=https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=J40txL-LXpM|accessdate=2017-09-30}}</ref> [[NDTV]], and [[TED (conference)|TED]].<ref>{{Citation|last=TEDx Talks|title=Success, Wisdom and Dogs {{!}} Rakesh Shukla {{!}} TEDxICTMumbai|date=2017-08-03|url=https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=WKIJ9flJZLo|accessdate=2017-09-30}}</ref> Shukla features in the book ''Real Inspiring Stories'' by Pradeep Khare.<ref>{{Cite web|url=https://books.google.co.in/books?id=BCNqCwAAQBAJ&pg=PA191&lpg=PA191&dq=rakesh+shukla+TWB&source=bl&ots=kORE-qNaru&sig=ZXjtA6UBvx9BiZNaxv-BWZbhLRs&hl=en&sa=X&ved=0ahUKEwiGttzAhIrUAhWJuo8KHT4wBHw4ChDoAQhWMAk#v=onepage&q=rakesh%20shukla%20TWB&f=false|title=Real Inspiring Stories by Maj (Retd.) Pradeep Khare|last=|first=|date=|website=|archive-url=|archive-date=|dead-url=|access-date=}}</ref>
One of the recent VOSD campaigns, called "Patriotdogs",<ref>{{Cite web|url=https://www.ketto.org/fundraiser/patriotdogs|title=Help VOSD bring home 100 #PatriotDogs! by The Voice of Stray Dogs (VOSD)|last=Ketto.org|website=Ketto.org|access-date=2017-09-30}}</ref> providing homes for dogs retiring from the Indian security and military forces, got widespread support from celebrities like [[Virat Kohli]]<ref>{{Cite web|url=https://twitter.com/imVkohli/status/847374668143120384|title=Help @VOSD1 bring home 100 #PatriotDogs! They spend their lives serving us, it's time to do something for them.|last=Kohli|first=Virat|date=2017-03-30|website=@imVkohli|language=en|archive-url=|archive-date=|dead-url=|access-date=2017-09-30}}</ref> and Soha Ali Khan Patuadi,<ref>{{Cite web|url=https://www.instagram.com/p/BRkWsAmBTgr/|title=Instagram post by Soha • Mar 13, 2017 at 6:20am UTC|website=Instagram|language=en|access-date=2017-09-30}}</ref> and it was featured in publications including the ''[[Times of India]]'',<ref>{{Cite news|url=http://timesofindia.indiatimes.com/city/bengaluru/a-sanctuary-where-patriot-dogs-spend-autumn-years/articleshow/57834418.cms|title=A sanctuary where patriot dogs spend autumn years - Times of India|work=The Times of India|access-date=2017-09-30}}</ref> the ''[[New Indian Express]]'',<ref>{{Cite news|url=http://www.newindianexpress.com/cities/bengaluru/2017/mar/20/patriotdogs-look-for-shelter-and-game-of-fetch-1583633.html|title=#Patriotdogs look for shelter and game of fetch|work=The New Indian Express|access-date=2017-09-30}}</ref> ''Sportstartlive'',<ref>{{Cite news|url=http://www.sportstarlive.com/starlife/sports-stars-support-campaign-for-retired-army-dogs/article17897169.ece|title=Kohli, Gayle support campaign for retired army dogs|work=Sportstarlive|access-date=2017-09-30|language=en}}</ref> [[MTV India]],<ref>{{Cite web|url=http://www.mtvindia.com/blogs/parent/news/retired-patriot-dogs-have-no-adopters-but-they-can-still-have-a-home-heres-how-you-can-help-52200498.html|title=Retired Patriot Dogs have no adopters|last=|first=|date=23 March 2017|website=MTV India|archive-url=|archive-date=|dead-url=|access-date=}}</ref> and the ''[[Deccan Chronicle]]''.<ref>{{Cite web|url=http://www.deccanchronicle.com/lifestyle/viral-and-trending/200317/patriot-gains-in-pooch-land.html|title=Patriot Gains in Pooch land|last=|first=|date=|website=Deccan Chronicle|archive-url=|archive-date=|dead-url=|access-date=}}</ref>

{{Use South African English|date=January 2015}} {{Use dmy dates|date=January 2015}} {{Infobox tennis biography |name=Rik de Voest |image=Rik-de-voest.jpg |country={{RSA}} |residence=[[Pretoria]], South Africa/ [[Vancouver]], [[Canada]] |birth_date={{Birth date and age|df=yes|1980|6|5}} |birth_place=[[Milan]], Italy |height={{height|m=1.80}} |turnedpro=1999 |retired=2014 |plays=Right-handed (two-handed backhand) |careerprizemoney=$1,344,871 |singlesrecord=32–54 |singlestitles=0
6 [[ATP Challenger Tour|Challenger]], 8 [[ITF Men's Circuit|Futures]] |highestsinglesranking=No. 110 (21 August 2006) |currentsinglesranking= |AustralianOpenresult=1R ([[2012 Australian Open – Men's Singles|2012]]) |FrenchOpenresult=Q3 ([[2008 French Open - Men's Singles#Qualifying|2008]]) |Wimbledonresult=2R ([[2011 Wimbledon Championships – Men's Singles|2011]]) |USOpenresult=2R ([[2007 US Open – Men's Singles|2007]]) |doublesrecord=45–48 |doublestitles=2 |highestdoublesranking=No. 39 (4 June 2009) |currentdoublesranking= |AustralianOpenDoublesresult=2R (2008, 2009) |FrenchOpenDoublesresult=3R (2009) |WimbledonDoublesresult=2R (2008) |USOpenDoublesresult=3R (2008) |updated=5 May 2014 }} '''Rik de Voest''' (born 5 June 1980) is a former professional [[South Africa]]n [[tennis player]]. His career-high singles ranking was World No. 110, which he achieved in August 2006. Rik currently resides in Vancouver, Canada where he pursues an active career in real estate specializing in [[North Vancouver (city)|North Vancouver]] and [[West Vancouver]] properties. De Voest qualified for the [[2007 Wimbledon Championships|2007]] [[The Championships, Wimbledon|Wimbledon]] [[2007 Wimbledon Championships – Men's Singles|men's singles event]], where he lost to [[Marat Safin]] in the first round. De Voest qualified for the [[2007 U.S. Open (tennis)|U.S. Open]] later on in 2007, where he defeated [[Thierry Ascione]] 6–2, 3–0 before Ascione retired. De Voest went on to lose to [[John Isner]] in the following round. De Voest is 12–5 in [[Davis Cup]] matches; being 8–5 for singles and 4–0 for doubles. Playing with [[Scott Lipsky]] of the U.S., he won the [[2009 Levene Gouldin & Thompson Tennis Challenger – Doubles|Levene Gouldin & Thompson Tennis Challenger]] in Binghamton, New York in 2009. ==ATP career finals== ===Doubles: 3 (2–1)=== {|class=wikitable style=font-size:97% !Legend (Doubles) |-bgcolor=f3e6d7 |Grand Slam (0–0) |-bgcolor=ffffcc |ATP World Tour Finals (0–0) |-bgcolor=e9e9e9 |ATP World Tour Masters 1000 (0–0) |-bgcolor=d4f1c5 |ATP World Tour 500 Series (1–0) |- |ATP World Tour 250 Series (1–1) |} {|class=wikitable style=font-size:97% !Outcome !No. !Date !Tournament !Surface !Partner !Opponent !Score |- |bgcolor=98FB98|Winner |1. |September 2007 |[[China Open (tennis)|China Open]], Beijing, China |Hard |{{flagicon|AUS}} [[Ashley Fisher]] |{{flagicon|RSA}} [[Chris Haggard]]

[[Image:BlakeMalkin.jpg|thumb|William Blake's frontispiece to ''A Father's Memoirs of his Child'' (1806), engraved by Cromek.]] '''Robert Hartley Cromek''' (1770–1812) was an English engraver, editor, art dealer and entrepreneur who was most active in the early nineteenth century. He is best known for having allegedly cheated [[William Blake]] out of the potential profits of his engraving depicting Chaucer's [[Canterbury Pilgrims]]. In the early years of the nineteenth century Cromek had supported Blake, and had engraved Blake's design for [[Benjamin Heath Malkin]]'s ''A Father's Memoirs of his Child'' in 1806. Cromek later commissioned Blake to illustrate [[Robert Blair (poet)|Robert Blair]]'s poem ''The Grave''. Blake had produced the designs, but his sample engraving was considered by Cromek to be too crude to attract subscribers. Cromek then gave the lucrative job of engraving Blake's designs to a rival engraver [[Luigi Schiavonetti]]. In response, Blake proceeded to create a self-engraved illustration to Chaucer's ''Canterbury Tales''. Cromek, however, had also given the idea to Blake's friend [[Thomas Stothard]]. Stothard's print became far more popular than Blake's, at least during their lifetimes. It remains unclear whether Blake or Cromek originated this project, but Blake certainly believed that the idea was stolen from him. The incident destroyed the friendship between Blake and Stothard.Blake v. Cromek: A Contemporary Ruling, J. B. Mertz, ''Modern Philology'', Vol. 99, No. 1 (Aug., 2001), pp. 66-77 As a savagely humorous comment on these events Blake wrote epigrams attacking Cromek:Keynes, Geoffrey, ''Blake: Complete Writings with variant readings'', Oxford University Press, 1972, p.540
Cromek loves artists as he loves his meat:
He loves the Art; but 'tis the art to cheat.

A petty sneaking knave I knew--
"O! Mr. Cromek, how do ye do?"
In 1809 Cromek published ''Remains of Nithsdale and Galloway Song'', a collection of Scottish ballads. The aspirant poet [[Allan Cunningham (author)|Allan Cunningham]] sent in poems of his own authorship, which Cromek included in the collection, even though he may have suspected their real authorship. About that time Cromek also compiled "RELIQUES OF ROBERT BURNS; Consisting Chiefly of Original Letters, Poems, and Critical Observations on Scottish Songs ". The original edition of 1808 contained a 4-page work by Thomas Stothard, "The Procession of Chaucer's Pilgrims to Canterbury", which did not appear in some later editions. His son was the artist [[Thomas Hartley Cromek]].{{cite news|last=Fowler|first=James|title=A Biographical Notice of Thomas Hartley Cromek, Esq.|url=http://en.wikisource.org/wiki/Wakefield_Express/Thomas_Hartley_Cromek|newspaper=Wakefield Express|date=19 April 1873}} ==References== {{Reflist}} {{Authority control}} {{DEFAULTSORT:Cromek, Robert}} [[Category:People associated with William Blake]] [[Category:1770 births]] [[Category:1812 deaths]] [[Category:Engravers]]
